title-group.article-title: Parents’ and Children’s Beliefs About Peer Victimization
title-group.subtitle: Attributions, Coping Responses, and Child Adjustment

author-notes.corresp: Bridgette D. Harper, Department of Psychology, Auburn University Montgomery, P.O. Box 244023, Montgomery, AL 36124 Email: bharper3@aum.edu

fn.p: Bridgette D. Harper is an assistant professor in the Department of Psychology at Auburn University Montgomery where she teaches coursework in life span and child development. She received her PhD in psychological sciences at the University of Texas at Dallas.

abstract.p: This study examined how parents’ and children’s beliefs about peer victimization are related to children’s adjustment. A mediational model was proposed that addressed how adjustment is predicted by degree of victimization, as well as causal attributions of and coping responses to victimization. The participants were 100 fifth- or sixth-grade children and one of their parents (primarily mothers). Children’s ages ranged from 10 to12 years of age (M = 10 years and 10 months, SD = 6 months). Using procedures recommended by Kenny, Kashy, and Bolger, mediational models were examined using multiple regression analyses. Results for child ratings supported the hypothesis that the association between peer victimization and psychosocial maladjustment is mediated through characterological blame attributions; this pattern of association was evident within parent-report data as well. Coping responses were not significant mediators in the models that examined the predictors of maladjustment from perceived victimization, attributions, and coping responses.

body.p: Recent media attention linking rare, but sometimes fatal, school violence to a history of peer victimization (Verlinden, Hersen, & Thomas, 2000) has increased public concern about the risks associated with being a victim of peer victimization. More commonly, however, peer victimization is linked to a host of problems contributing to the overall quality of children’s daily lives including peer rejection, poorer academic performance, dislike and avoidance of school, higher levels of anxiety, depression and loneliness, along with lower self-esteem (Haynie et al., 2001; Kochenderfer-Ladd & Wardrop, 2001; Olweus, 1992; Rigby, 2000). However, not all children who experience peer victimization suffer these negative consequences. Results of studies suggest that children’s coping responses and attributions in relation to peer victimization may influence subsequent psychosocial adjustment (Graham & Juvonen, 1998; Kochenderfer-Ladd & Skinner, 2002).

The present study was designed to investigate the relationship between peer victimization, causal attributions, coping responses, and child adjustment (see Figure 1). Much of the previous research in this area has focused on the relationship between middle-school-age children’s peer victimization experiences and attributions. However, there is evidence to suggest that for children as young as 8 years old, attributions are becoming significant predictors of coping behaviors. For example, several studies have found significant relationships between attribution of intent and subsequent aggressive behavior for early adolescent age children (see Orobio de Castro, Veerman, Koops, Bosch, & Monshouwer, 2002 for a full review). Therefore, the current study investigated the relationship of these variables for early adolescent children. The attributions that were investigated include characterological self-blame (internal, stable), behavioral self-blame (internal, not stable), and peer-blame (external). The research focused on whether the relationship between perceived peer victimization and psychosocial adjustment is mediated through both attributions and coping responses (see Figure 1). When studied separately, coping responses and attributions have been found to directly influence children’s psychosocial adjustment following peer victimization (Graham & Juvonen, 2002; Kochenderfer-Ladd & Skinner, 2002; see Figure 1). However, it could be the case that causal attributions influence psychosocial adjustment indirectly through the influence on selection of coping responses (see Figure 1). However, as attributions and coping responses are not typically investigated simultaneously, we do not know whether both these internal processes incrementally influence children’s adjustment and whether they mediate the influence of stress? Furthermore, will the observed relationships between perceived peer victimization and children’s adjustment be evident within parent-report data and across parent- and child-report data?

caption.p: Integrated model of peer victimization, attributions, coping responses, and child adjustment

sec.title: Peer Victimization, Attributions, and Psychosocial Adjustment
sec.p: Previous studies using hypothetical vignettes depicting episodes of peer victimization have found that children who report experiencing higher levels of peer victimization are more likely to endorse characterological self-blame attributions than are children who report less peer victimization and that these attributions are linked to poorer psychosocial adjustment (Graham, 2005; Graham, Bellmore, & Mize, 2006; Graham & Juvonen, 1998, 2002). In addition, Prinstein, Cheah, and Guyer (2005), using ambiguous hypothetical vignettes, found that victimized children made significantly more critical self-referent attributions (internal, stable, and negative attributions about their own character) than did nonvictimized children, and these attributions were significantly associated with maladaptive psychological adjustment, including, social anxiety, loneliness, low self-esteem, and higher levels of depressive symptoms. Furthermore, characterological self-blame has been found to partially mediate the relationship between peer victimization and psychosocial adjustment (Graham & Juvonen, 1998) and peer victimization and school adjustment (Graham et al., 2006).

Together, these studies suggest that characterological self-blame is an important factor in how children adjust to peer victimization. Overall, children who report experiencing more frequent peer victimization are more likely to make characterological self-blaming attributions compared with those who make peer-blame or behavioral self-blame attributions, and characterological self-blame, in turn, appears to be linked to higher levels of anxiety, loneliness, and depressive symptoms along with lower feelings of self-worth. The hypothesis that attributions mediate the relationship between perceived victimization and internalizing problems has received the least attention to date; however, there is limited evidence that characterological self-blame partially mediates the relationship between peer victimization and child outcomes (Graham et al., 2006; Graham & Juvonen, 1998). These tentative findings clearly warrant further investigation. Also, in the previous work, external attributions have been virtually ignored. Peer-blaming attributions, however, should at least in theory be more adaptive for children than behavioral and characterological self-blame. The possible mediation of peer victimization and adjustment through internal and external attributions is explored in the present study.

sec.title: Peer Victimization, Coping Responses, and Adjustment
sec.p: Research investigating the relationship between peer victimization and children’s coping strategies finds modest to moderate associations between the frequency of peer victimization and children’s greater use of emotion-focused coping responses (Andreou, 2001; Compas, Connor-Smith, Saltzman, Thomsen, & Wadsworth, 2001; Skinner & Zimmer-Gembeck, 2007; Smith, Shu, & Madsen, 2001; Smith, Talamelli, Cowie, Naylor, & Chauhan, 2004). However, there has been less research on the ways that different coping responses to peer victimization affect psychosocial adjustment. Kochenderfer-Ladd and Skinner (2002) investigated the relationship between children’s coping responses to peer victimization and their psychosocial adjustment and found that distancing, emotion-focused, and externalizing coping responses were modestly correlated with self-reported loneliness and teacher-rated anxious-depressed tendencies. Furthermore, Kochenderfer-Ladd and Skinner (2002) also found that approach coping responses moderated the relationship between victimization and psychological outcomes. They found that infrequently victimized children who reported using more approach coping strategies such as problem solving had lower levels of loneliness and fewer social problems than did more frequently victimized children. Furthermore, Kochenderfer-Ladd (2004) also found that seeking revenge was modestly related to higher levels of subsequent peer victimization, whereas conflict resolution was associated with lower levels of internalizing problems; however, these relationships were mediated through emotional responses. For example, the relationship between peer victimization and advice-seeking and conflict resolution was mediated through fear (i.e., reports of feeling afraid if they are victimized), and the relationship between revenge-seeking and subsequent peer victimization was mediated through anger and embarrassment (Kochenderfer-Ladd, 2004).

Due to limited research investigating the issue of whether coping responses mediate the relationship between peer victimization and children’s psychological adjustment, there is clearly a need for more research investigating these linkages. This is an important issue because it gets at the heart of the question of whether, and to what extent, intervening coping processes account for the individual variation in maladjustment following victimization. In addition, although we know that emotional responses may influence the responses children make to peer victimization, almost no studies have examined how other intervening psychological processes might influence the type of coping responses children use. For example, children’s beliefs about the cause of victimization (e.g., “there is something about me or my behavior that caused this vs. these kids are just mean to everyone?”) may influence the types of coping responses children make (e.g., “ignore them,” “seek help from a teacher,” or “cry”). However, research has typically investigated causal attributions and coping responses separately despite conceptual reasons to think that attributions may influence coping strategy selections and that both attributions and coping strategies together influence psychological adjustment to peer victimization.

Therefore, the present study sought to extend previous work by simultaneously assessing the roles of attributions and coping responses in children’s subsequent adjustment to peer victimization. To examine whether the associations among victimization, attributions, coping, and maladjustment also emerge from other informants’ data, parent-report assessments were also gathered. This additional source of assessment provides the opportunity to test whether similar patterns of associations emerge within parent ratings and to test whether associations hold up across independent child- and parent-report assessments. However, parents’ ratings of internal adjustment may not be as accurate as their ratings of external adjustment, as parents may not be aware of their children’s internal experiences. Even so, parent-report data shed light on the extent to which parents are aware of their children’s peer victimization experiences and what they see as consequences of victimization.

sec.title: Goals and Predictions
sec.p: The first goal of this study was to examine whether the relationship between peer victimization and children’s adjustment is mediated through attributions and coping responses. The second goal was to examine how attributions about peer victimization influence children’s coping responses. Figure 1 presents a model that depicts the possible relationships among victimization, causal attributions, coping responses, and psychosocial adjustment. However, determining the direction of the relationship between these variables is complex. For example, peer victimization could lead children to be more depressed, lonelier, and more anxious; however, it is also possible that children with poorer psychosocial adjustment have smaller support systems and may be easier to victimize. In relation to coping and attributions, it could be the case that victimization causes children to make certain attributions and to choose certain coping responses; however, certain attributions and coping responses could make children more vulnerable to being victimized (Graham & Juvonen, 1998; Kochenderfer-Ladd & Skinner, 2002). Even though it is difficult to establish directionality among these variables, the current study proposes a model and utilizes meditational techniques that could potentially help establish possible directional links. The basic idea of this model is that causal attributions and coping responses are both intervening psychological processes, with causal attributions likely influencing psychosocial adjustment directly and indirectly through influence on selection of coping responses. More specifically, characterological self-blame attributions may cause children to feel hopeless to change their situation, thus making them more likely to employ emotion-focused coping responses such as feeling sorry for yourself (see Figure 1). Therefore, it was predicted that children who endorse more characterological self-blame beliefs will report higher levels of peer victimization, endorse more emotion-focused coping responses and fewer approach responses, and exhibit poorer psychosocial adjustment.

Less is known about the potential benefits or drawbacks of behavioral self-blaming and external peer-blaming attributions. However, children who make behavioral self-blaming attributions or external peer-blaming attributions may have some hope of improving their situation because they are not blaming the peer victimization on something internal and stable about themselves. Therefore, it was predicted that children who endorse more behavioral self-blame and external peer-blame beliefs will report lower levels of peer victimization, endorse more approach coping responses, and exhibit better psychosocial adjustment than children who endorse more characterological self-blame beliefs.

The second goal of this study was to investigate how parents arrive at their beliefs about how their children should cope with peer victimization. A number of researchers have hypothesized that parents can assist children in dealing with peer relationships (Parke & Ladd, 1992). In fact, research indicates that even in early adolescence, parents remain involved and continue to retain considerable influence over their children’s peer relationships (Engels, Dekovic, & Meeus, 2002). However, research aimed specifically toward the influence of parenting on peer relationships is scarce. Therefore, the current study examines how parents believe their children should cope with peer victimization and what factors determine those beliefs.

The current study predicts that the process by which parents arrive at their views about how their children should cope with peer victimization largely parallels the psychological processes that children engage in when selecting coping responses, with a few notable exceptions. Once parents are aware that their children are victimized, they are likely to try to determine the cause of the victimization; thus, they engage in an attributional analysis parallel to children’s attributional processing. Like children, parents consider the frequency of victimization: the more frequent the victimization, the more likely that parents will believe their children are partially or fully to blame. In contrast to the children themselves, parents’ attributions are likely to be influenced by the “actor-observer” bias that social psychologists have documented (Jones & Nisbett, 1972). In contrast to actors who are biased toward making external situational attributions for things that happen to them, observers tend to attribute relatively more causal influence to the actor’s own stable personality traits. As observers, parents are also likely to consider their children’s stable personality characteristics, especially those that may provoke aggression from peers. Thus, if a child has a history of provocative (externalizing behavioral tendencies) or submissive (internalizing behavioral tendencies), parents may be more likely to blame the child for evoking victimization from peers.

On the basis of their decisions about causality, parents may arrive at different beliefs about how their children should cope with peer victimization. In theory, it is important to understand this process because parents may share their beliefs with their children and thereby exert influence on how children cope with peer victimization. The current study predicts that parents who make behavioral child-blame attributions are likely to endorse approach strategies such as trying to get along with the victimizer or seeking help and advice. This is because blaming their children’s behavior focuses the cause of the victimization on something less stable and modifiable. Thus, there is hope for stopping and preventing victimization if children can simply modify what they do or say to deescalate and prevent peer victimization. However, parents who make characterological child-blame attributions are likely to endorse avoidant strategies such as cognitive distancing. This is because blaming something stable and nonchangeable about their child’s behavior leaves very little hope for actively changing the situation, and therefore, the best strategy is to avoid the victimizer and downplay the emotional effect.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Participants were 100 parent–child dyads, primarily middle class, recruited from two elementary schools and through flyers distributed at after-school programs that were not affiliated with the city’s public school system in a southwestern U.S. city (56 boys and 44 girls). Children’s ages ranged from 10 to 12 years of age, (M = 10 years and 10 months, SD = 6 months). One school had a total of 4 fifth-grade classroom consisting of 102 fifth-grade children. Of these children, 43 returned their permission slips, a return rate of 42%. Of the 42% of families who returned their permission slips, 34 families or 79% of families chose to participate. The other school consisted of three fifth-grade classrooms with a total of 61 fifth-grade students. Of these students, 24 or 39% returned their permission slips. Of the 39% of families who returned their permission slips, 18 families or 75% chose to participate in the study. Data were collected from 60 families recruited through flyers and 40 recruited through the schools. The flyer contained information about the study along with contact information. When the family contacted the researcher, they were given more information about the study. At this time, if the family desired to participate, an interview was scheduled with the family. A t test revealed no significant differences, t(98) = .69, p < .49, between child-reported victimization by peers for the children recruited through flyers, M = 1.79, and for the children recruited through the public schools, M = 1.72.

Assessment was done during the spring of children’s fifth-grade or sixth-grade year of school. Of the sample, 83.5% were White, 10.3% were Hispanic, and 6.2% were African American. Although the current sample represented the upper middle class, it was not a mirror reflection of the demographics of the broader school system; 71% White, 18.2% Hispanic, and 7.2% African American.

The child’s primary caregiver (defined as the caregiver who interacts with the child the most on a day-to-day basis and has the most intimate knowledge of the child’s peer interactions) was asked to participate in the study. This was most often the mother (n = 96).

sec.title: Procedures
sec.p: Interviews with the participating parent and child took place at their homes. Children were interviewed individually by trained undergraduate and graduate students, whereas the participating parents completed their questionnaires in a separate room to ensure independent responses from both the parent and the child. On concluding the interview session, the parent and child were compensated US$15 each for participating.

sec.title: Social Experience Questionnaire (SEQ)
sec.p: To obtain information about the frequency of perceived peer victimization, the SEQ (Crick & Grotpeter, 1995) was administered to both parents and children. The SEQ consisted of 10 items that assessed how often children perceived that they experienced peer victimization, and a parallel version was given to parents in which the wording was changed to reflect how often parents perceived that their children were victimized. For example, the question for children, “How often do you get pushed or shoved by another child at school?” was restated for parents as “How often does your child get pushed or shoved by another child at school?” Parents indicated on a 5-point Likert-type scale how often they perceived that their child had experienced the behavior described in each statement with 1 indicating never experienced, 5 indicating all the time experienced, and 3 indicating sometimes experienced. Children used the same scale to rate how often they had experienced the events. Scores were calculated by averaging across the 10 items.

sec.title: Attribution Questionnaire
sec.p: Both children’s and parents’ attributions were measured with an Attribution Questionnaire designed to assess attributions about peer victimization (Graham & Juvonen, 1998). This measure consisted of a hypothetical scenario that depicted a child being victimized by peers beside his or her locker. Children and parents were instructed to imagine that this situation happened to them or to their child, then after reading the story, both children and parents rated their agreement with 16 different statements designed to assess characterological self-blame, behavioral self-blame, and external-other blame. The wording of these scales was modified for parents to reflect parental attributions about why the hypothetical situation would have happened to their child. Scores for children’s attributions were calculated following the procedures outlined by Graham and Juvonen (1998). The alpha reliability coefficients of these three subscales were as follows: characterological self-blame, α = .83; behavioral self-blame, α = .68; and peer-blame, α = .55. One item, “How can my child keep this from happening again” was left out of the subscales as it did not meet the criteria.

As the attribution measure was modified for parents, their ratings were subjected to an exploratory factor analysis using principal factors extraction with oblique rotation. Scale scores were created from the variables with loadings of .40 or higher for each factor. One item, “How can my child keep this from happening again” was left out of the subscales as it did not meet the criteria. Three factors emerged that paralleled those that Graham and Juvonen (1998) found in their factor analysis of child ratings on these scales (see Table 1). Scores were computed following procedures outlined by Graham and Juvonen (1998).

caption.p: Factor Loadings for the Attribution Measure (Parent Data)

tr.td: Why does my child always get into these situations?
I know this will happen to my child again
These kids do this to my child because other kids also treat my child this way
This sort of thing is more likely to happen to my child than to other kids
If my child were a cooler kid, he or she wouldn’t get picked on
Kids do this to my child because they know he or she will not cause trouble
There are too many kids who wanna be tough
My child needs to figure out how to deal with this kind of situation
Kids do this to my child because they know my child will not get back at them?
This is my child’s fault, he or she shouldn’t have been in the hallway alone
My child was at the wrong place at the wrong time
My child should have been more careful
My child shouldn’t have been here at this time

fn.label: a.
fn.p: Factors I, II, and III accounted for 27.6%, 11.5%, and 10.9% of the variance, respectively.

sec.title: Coping Scale
sec.p: Children’s and parents’ coping strategies were measured with a modified version of the Causey and Dubow’s (1992) Self-Report Coping Measure for Elementary School Children (Kochenderfer-Ladd & Skinner, 2002). The revised scale (Kochenderfer-Ladd & Skinner, 2002) consists of 26 strategies; children are asked to rate how likely they would be to use each strategy if a child were being mean to them either by calling them names or hitting and pushing them. Parents were administered a parallel version with modified wording to reflect how parents believe their children should cope with peer victimization. Both children and parents were asked to indicate their responses on a 3-point scale where 1 = no would not/would not advise, 2 = maybe, and 3 = yes I would do that/ I would advise to do that. The questions were designed to assess the following coping strategies: advice and social support seeking (i.e., “would you ask a parent what you should do”), cognitive distancing (i.e., “would you make believe nothing happened?”), conflict resolution (i.e., “would you tell the child to stop?”), and emotion-focused strategies (i.e., “would you feel sorry for yourself?”). Following procedures outlined by Kochenderfer-Ladd and Skinner (2002), scores for children’s coping responses were calculated by averaging across the respective items on each scale. The alpha reliability coefficients of these four subscales were as follows: social support seeking, α = .84; distancing, α = .79; conflict resolution, α = .41; and emotion focused coping, α = .31. As the coping measure was modified for parents, their ratings were subjected to an exploratory factor analysis using principal factors extraction with varimax rotation (see Kochenderfer-Ladd & Skinner, 2002 for review). Two factors that could be meaningfully interpreted were identified (see Table 2).

caption.p: Factor Loadings for the Coping Measure (Parent Data)

tr.td: Should your child tell himself or herself it didn’t matter?
Should your child make believe nothing happened?
Should your child tell himself or herself it was no big deal?
Should your child try to forget it ever happened?
Should your child just walk away?
Should your child ask a parent to do something about it?
Should your child talk to a friend about how it made him or her feel?
Should your child ask a parent what he or she should do?
Should your child ask his or her teacher what to do?
Should your child talk to a parent about what happened?
Should your child tell a friend about what happened?
Should your child ask his or her teacher to do something about it?

fn.label: a.
fn.p: Factors I and II accounted for 17.5% and 13.8% of the variance, respectively.

sec.title: Revised Children’s Manifest Anxiety Scale (RCMAS)
sec.p: Children’s anxiety was measured with the RCMAS, a 37-item self-report scale designed to assess three subscales, social anxiety, physiological anxiety, and worry along with a total anxiety score (Reynolds & Richmond, 1985). For the current study, the total anxiety score was used for all analyses. Scores were calculated by computing the total anxiety score, α = .87.

sec.title: Children’s Depression Inventory (CDI)
sec.p: Children’s level of depressive symptoms was measured with the CDI, which consists of 27 self-report items that present participants with three statements describing symptoms of depression (Kovaks, 1985). Participants indicated which statement best described how they had been feeling within the last 2 weeks. Two items of the CDI that assess suicidal ideation and self-hate were omitted, and five positive filler items were added (Crick & Grotpeter, 1995). Scores were calculated by computing the total depression score, α = .81.

sec.title: Loneliness in Children
sec.p: To obtain information about children’s feelings of loneliness, the Loneliness in Children measure (Asher, Hymel, & Renshaw, 1984) was administered to the children. This measure consisted of 16 items that assessed children’s feelings of loneliness such as “I feel lonely” or “I have lots of friends” and 8 distracter items such as “I like to paint and draw.” Children indicated on a 5-point Likert-type scale how true each statement was about them with 1 indicating always true about them, 3 indicating true sometimes, and 5 indicating not true at all. Scores were calculated by averaging across the 16 loneliness items, α = .85.

sec.title: Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL)
sec.p: To obtain parental reports of children’s internalizing and externalizing behavioral tendencies, parents completed the CBCL (ages 6-18). This test assessed child behavior and social competence. The questionnaire included questions that asked parents to rate their children’s behaviors (on a scale of 0 = not true, 1 = somewhat true or 2 = true), including behaviors indicative of internalizing and externalizing behavioral tendencies. Children’s internalizing and externalizing scores as rated by parents were used for all analyses.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Hypotheses were tested by conducting correlational analyses and multiple regression analyses. Results are presented in two sections. The first section reports preliminary analyses focusing on descriptive information for all the variables. The second section focuses on testing hypotheses about direct and indirect relationships among perceived peer victimization, attributions, coping responses, and children’s psychological adjustment.

sec.title: Preliminary Analyses
sec.p: Results of preliminary descriptive analyses of perceived peer victimization, causal attributions for victimization, and the endorsement of different coping responses according to child report and parent report are shown in Tables 3 and 4. In the current study, both parents and children reported relatively low levels of victimization. More interestingly, the correlation between parent perceptions of peer victimization and children’s perceptions of peer victimization was relatively low, r = .21 (see Table 5), indicating that parent and child perceptions of the child’s victimization experiences were only modestly related.

caption.p: Correlations Between Parent and Child Measures

fn.p: Note: VIC = parent victimization; PB = peer-blame; CSB = characterological; BSB = behavioral; SS = social support; DIS = distancing; Anx = anxiety; Dep = depression; Lone = loneliness.

sec.title: Attributions
sec.p: Across parent- and child-report data, there was not a significant difference between peer-blame attributions, t(97) = −1.17, p < .24; however, parents’ and children’s means for characterological self-blame and behavioral self-blame differed significantly, t(97) = −5.60, p < .01 and t(97) = −12.07, p < .01, respectively. Thus, children reported more behavioral and characterological self-blame attributions, whereas parents reported fewer characterological child-blame and behavioral child-blame attributions (see Tables 3, 4, and 5).

sec.title: Coping
sec.p: A one-way analysis of variance revealed that even though it appeared that children tended to choose more conflict resolution strategies, the mean differences between conflict resolution strategies and social support seeking, distancing, and emotion-focused were not significant, F(5, 94) = 1.52, p < .19; F(5, 94) = .22, p < .95; and F(5, 94) = 1.00, p < 1.0, respectively. Parents tended to more readily endorse social support seeking strategies than distancing strategies, which was significantly different, t(97) = −15.57, p < .01.

sec.title: Gender
sec.p: Gender differences in the frequency of self-reported victimization, coping strategies, and attributions were examined. No significant effects of gender were found for any variables.

sec.title: Parent- and child-reported peer victimization and adjustment
sec.p: There was a significant relationship between child-perceived peer victimization and child-reported adjustment (see Table 3). Furthermore, parent-reported victimization was related to child internalizing and child externalizing problem behaviors (see Table 4). Results also revealed cross-informant relationships in that child-reported victimization was significantly correlated with parent-reported child externalizing behaviors (see Table 5).

sec.title: Parent- and child-reported peer victimization, attributions, and coping responses
sec.p: There was a significant relationship between child-perceived peer victimization and each attribution; however, within parent-report data, only characterological blame was significantly related to peer victimization. Across informants, parental-perceived peer victimization was significantly related to children’s behavioral self-blame attributions (see Tables 3, 4, and 5).

There was a significant relationship between child-perceived peer victimization and emotion-focused coping, but no significant correlations within parent-report data (see Tables 3 and 4). There were no significant cross-informant correlations (see Table 5).

sec.title: Parent- and child-reported attributions and coping
sec.p: Within child-report data, characterological self-blame was significantly related to emotion-focused coping; however, peer-blame and behavioral self-blame were not significantly related to coping strategies (see Table 3). Within parent-report data, attributions were not related to coping strategies (see Table 4). Across informants, no significant relationships were found for attributions and coping strategies (see Table 5).

sec.title: Parent- and child-reported attributions, coping responses, and adjustment
sec.p: Within child-reported data, peer-blame was significantly related to anxiety and depression; characterological self-blame was significantly related to all adjustment indices; and behavioral self-blame was significantly related to loneliness. Of the coping strategies assessed, only emotion-focused coping was significantly related to adjustment (see Table 3). Within parent-report data, peer-blame was significantly related to internalizing behaviors and characterological blame was significantly related to both internalizing and externalizing behaviors. No significant relationships between coping and adjustment emerged (see Table 4). Across parent- and child-report data, child-reported behavioral self-blame was significantly related to parent-reported internalizing and externalizing behaviors, and parent-reported distance coping was related to child-reported loneliness (see Table 5).

sec.title: Tests of Mediation
sec.p: On the basis of the results of the bivariate relations examined in the previous sections, initial criteria were met for testing six mediational processes, three from the child-report data, two from the parent-report data, and one examining across child and parent data (see Kenny Kashy & Bolger, 1998 for a review of mediation criteria). The results of this mediational testing are presented in Table 6. The table presents results of the six regression analyses designed to test for mediation. The table includes standardized betas and R2 for both Model 1 and for Model 2.

caption.p: Regression Analyses Testing Mediation of the Association Between Peer Victimization and Children’s Adjustment From Child- and Parent-Report Data

fn.p: Note: “—” indicates that the Step 1 or Step 2 criteria for mediation were not established for the variable.

fn.label: a.
fn.p: Indicates results of mediational analysis between parent and child data.

sec.title: Mediation analyses within child-report data
sec.p: The mediational analysis for anxiety as the outcome variable included child-perceived peer victimization as the independent variable and characterological self-blame attributions, peer-blame attributions, and emotion-focused coping as the mediators. The prediction of child-reported anxiety from child-perceived peer victimization, as indicated by the standardized betas in the two regression models decreased from .47 to .26, a reduction of 45%, but remained significant, indicating that characterological self-blame partially mediated (Sobel test, z = 2.93, p < .01) the relation between child-perceived peer victimization and anxiety (see Table 6).

The mediational analysis for depressive symptoms included child-perceived victimization as the independent variable and characterological self-blame attributions, peer-blame attributions, and emotion-focused coping as the mediators. The prediction of child-reported depressive symptoms by child-perceived peer victimization decreased from .40 to .15, a reduction of 63%, which was no longer significant, indicating full mediation (Sobel test, z = 3.47, p < .01).

The mediational analysis for loneliness included child-perceived peer victimization as the independent variable and characterological self-blame attributions, behavioral self-blame attributions and emotion-focused coping responses as the mediators. The prediction of child-reported loneliness by child-perceived peer victimization decreased from .45 to .24, a reduction of 47%, but remained significant with the mediators included in the model, indicating partial mediation (Sobel test, z = 2.29, p < .05).

sec.title: Mediational analyses within parent-report data
sec.p: The mediational analysis for parent ratings of internalizing behavior included parent-perceived peer victimization as the independent variable and parental-rated characterological child-blame attributions as the mediator. As shown in Table 6, under Model 2, the prediction of internalizing behaviors by parent-perceived peer victimization decreased from .51 to .37, a reduction of 28%, but remained significant with the mediator included in the regression model, indicating partial mediation (Sobel test, z = 2.61, p < .05). Thus characterological child-blame partially mediated this relationship.

The mediational analysis for externalizing problems included parent-perceived peer victimization as the independent variable and parental characterological child-blame attributions as the mediator. The prediction of parent-rated externalizing child problem behaviors by parent-perceived peer victimization decreased from .47 to .44, a reduction of 7%, which was not significant. This relationship was not mediated by parental reports of externalizing child problem behaviors (Sobel test, z = .70, p < .48).

sec.title: Mediational analysis across parent- and child-report data
sec.p: On the basis of Steps 1, 2, and 3, criteria were met for only one mediational model across parent- and child-report data: the mediational analysis included parent-reported child externalizing behaviors as the outcome variable, child-perceived peer victimization as the independent variable, and child behavioral self-blame attributions as the hypothesized mediator. As shown in Table 6, under Model 2, the prediction of parent-reported externalizing behaviors by child-perceived peer victimization decreased .21 to .16, a reduction of 24%, which was no longer significant, indicating full mediation. However, Sobel test (z = 1.64, p = .10) indicated that this mediation was not significant.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The main purpose of this study was to determine whether the relationship between perceived peer victimization and psychosocial maladjustment could be accounted for by two mediating mental processes, causal attributions, and coping responses, and, if so, are these processes apparent in both child- and parent-report data. The findings revealed that peer victimization was moderately to strongly associated with child-reported anxiety, depression, and loneliness and with parent-reported internalizing and externalizing problems. Victimization was also associated with characterological self-blame attributions within both child- and parent-report ratings but was only modestly related to emotion-focused coping in child-report ratings. Self-blaming attribution patterns incrementally increase the prediction of adjustment problems beyond victimization, but coping strategies did not add to prediction. There was consistent evidence that self-blame attributions mediated the relationship between victimization and child reports of anxiety, depression, and loneliness and parent-reported internalizing problems.

sec.title: Attributions and Coping as Mediators of the Effects of Victimization on Adjustment
sec.p: Consistent with expectations and findings from several past studies, perceived frequency of peer victimization was robustly related to child-reported loneliness, depression, and anxiety and to parent-reported internalizing and externalizing problems (Graham & Juvonen, 1998; Kochenderfer-Ladd & Skinner, 2002). Within child report and parent-report data, causal attributions were associated with both children’s socioemotional adjustment and levels of peer victimization, with characterological self-blaming attributions being most strongly associated with perceptions of peer victimization and children’s maladjustment. However, coping strategies were more weakly and less consistently related to adjustment within both parent- and child-report data. Mediational analyses revealed, as hypothesized, that attributions partially mediated the relationship between victimization and maladjustment, but there was little evidence that coping responses play a similar mediational role.

sec.title: Implications of the partial mediation through self-blame
sec.p: The fact that self-blame partially mediated the relationship between peer victimization and child adjustment suggests that peer victimization may have a direct effect on adjustment that is independent of any intervening processes, but that intervening processes, particularly characterological self-blame, have some influence on how children ultimately adjust to peer victimization. Therefore, simply changing a child’s attributional tendencies away from characterological self-blame would not eliminate entirely the ill effects of peer victimization, but it might alleviate some of the distress. Thus, based on these findings, there should be some partial reduction in maladjustment if we teach children not to attribute cause to their own internal stable characteristics. However, this may not be the best strategy in cases where children’s stable-internal traits actually are the cause of their being victimized. If this latter possibility is true, then trying to teach children to deceive themselves about the causes of victimization might be counterproductive and difficult to achieve. Logically, it seems it would be difficult to convince children who are called “freckle face” that they are not teased because of the freckles. In these cases, it may seem better to teach children to blame the peer for the victimization or to focus on possible behavioral causes of victimization (i.e., poor social skills or inappropriate responses to peer victimization). The current findings, however, suggest that this may not be the best strategy either. Although peer-blame attributions may protect children’s self-esteem (Graham & Juvonen, 2001), in the current study, peer-blame attributions were associated with modestly higher levels of anxiety and depression. Thus, children who perceived that their victimization was caused by uncontrollable events, such as a rough school or mean kids, also reported feeling more anxious and more depressed. Therefore, it is still unclear whether behavioral or external blame has any adaptive or maladaptive qualities. Some of this uncertainty could be a result of poor measurement of both behavioral self-blame and peer-blame attributions. For example, only three items could be identified for the Behavioral Self-Blame Scale, and the internal consistency of these items was low. There also may be other yet to be identified attributions that children make about victimization. In addition, the current study only assessed one hypothetical scenario of “public victimization in front of a locker.” However, children’s attributions may differ when the circumstances of peer victimization change (i.e., physical aggression, verbal aggression, social aggression, and teasing). Therefore, future research needs to identify victimized children who have relatively few internalizing problems and interview them to probe more carefully how they construe the causes of peer hostility toward them within a variety of social contexts.

sec.title: Coping responses
sec.p: There was far less support for the hypothesis that coping responses mediate the relationship between perceived peer victimization and psychological adjustment. Three of the four coping responses assessed in the current study were uncorrelated with levels of victimization and measures of maladjustment. The only coping response that was related to victimization and maladjustment was emotion-focused coping, which is in reality a negative form of coping (i.e., blaming self and feeling sorry for self). In the current study, this type of coping was associated with worse rather than better adjustment. Mediational analyses revealed that coping responses were not significant mediators of the relation between peer victimization and child reported outcomes. There was even less evidence of a significant role of coping in parent-report data in that parental-advised coping was not correlated with victimization or parent-reported adjustment.

sec.title: Implications of coping findings
sec.p: One possible conclusion is that coping responses play no, or only a very small, role in determining children’s socioemotional reactions to victimization. This conclusion would stand in contrast to the fairly clear evidence from past studies that instrumental coping responses do influence whether peers perpetuate victimization, with several studies showing that instrumental approach responses, when used effectively, reduce the likelihood of further victimization (Bijttebier & Vertommen, 1998; Phelps, 2001; Smith et al., 2004). However, the lack of positive socioemotional benefits associated with approach coping in the current study is interesting. Taken together, these findings paint an almost paradoxical picture: emotion-focused coping results in continuing abuse by peers but has little discernable effect on children’s adjustment to the abuse. Similarly, past research indicates that instrumental coping reduces frequency of attacks but seemingly has no systematic affect on emotional responses to attacks. However, perhaps evidence of a positive effect of instrumental approach coping could be detected if the effectiveness of the coping responses are controlled. In studies assessing the relationship between coping responses and the perpetuation of victimization, this has been the case and could be the case for coping responses and maladjustment as well.

Another possible explanation of the current findings is that the measures of coping responses were limited. Two of the four coping scales had low internal consistency. There also have been difficulties replicating the factor structure of the scales across studies (Kochenderfer-Ladd & Skinner, 2002) and across child and parent data in the current study as well. For example, for parents, only two factors—social support seeking and cognitive distancing—emerged. More interestingly, these were the two factors with the highest reliability for children as well. Perhaps parents have had some experience with the other coping strategies presented and have learned through this experience that these strategies do not work. Thus, both children and parents have some idea about what strategies do not work but have less idea about what could work. It could also be the case that the coping scale was limited in the types of strategies parents and children believe would be successful. Perhaps the types of coping responses examined should encompass a broader array of responses to victimization, including humor. For example, imagine a situation in which a girl is wearing an outfit that her peers begin to tease her about. She may get quite a different response from her peers if she laughs with them and says something along the line of, “I know. Isn’t it ridiculous, but my mom made me wear it,” as opposed to shutting down, becoming quiet, and “ignoring” or “snubbing” the offending peers. More psychometric work may be needed to develop measures that reliably and validly assess children’s coping responses.

It could also be the case that children’s emotions in relation to peer victimization mediate the relationship between causal attributions and children’s coping responses. Thus, contrary to the current study’s hypotheses, attributions may have an indirect effect on children’s coping responses. For example, Wiener’s two-phase theory of the emotions that follow negative events theorizes that these victimized kids get a double whammy (Weiner, 1995). First, they experience the immediate outcome-related unpleasant emotions of pain and embarrassment, and then they experience the postattribution emotions of lowered self-worth and depression because of self-blame. Weiner’s (1995) model argues that children should experience different emotions following from their attributions. Therefore, immediate emotions could potentially influence children’s causal attributions, and the postattribution emotions most likely influence children’s coping responses. Future research should explore this possibility.

sec.title: Attributions and coping responses as mediators of the effects of perceived peer victimization across parent and child data
sec.p: There were similar patterns of findings within both parent and child data for associations among victimization, attributions, and adjustment. However, there were very few across-informant correlations. Similar to past findings (see Ladd & Kochenderfer-Ladd, 2002 for a full review), the correlation between parent- and child-reported victimization was only r = .21. Similarly, parent reports of internalizing and externalizing child behaviors were correlated in the r = .15 to .28 range with child reports of loneliness, anxiety, and depression. Only one of the mediation models replicated across sources: The relationship between child-reported peer victimization and parent-reported externalizing behaviors was mediated by child behavioral self-blame attributions. The within-source (parent- and child-report data) replications boost confidence in our picture of the associations among the basic psychological processes. Lack of replication within these independent sources of data would have suggested that associations are only present in the minds of children. This does not appear to be the case, suggesting that parents’ and children’s reports reveal consistent patterns of associations among the variables. The lack of across-source associations can be interpreted in different ways.

A possible explanation for why this relationship did not hold across parent and child data could be a result of parents’ and children’s divergent perspectives on the frequency of peer victimization. In the current study, the correlation between parents’ and children’s perceptions of peer victimization was significant but low, about .21, indicating that parents and children did not agree about the basic facts about how often children are victimized. This is consistent with past findings that have compared peer and self-reports, with correlations ranging between r = .20 and .40, and those that have compared self-reports with parent and teacher reports, with correlations typically ranging between r = .17 and .30 (Graham & Juvonen, 1998; Kochenderfer-Ladd & Skinner, 2002; Ladd & Kochenderfer-Ladd, 2002; Pellegrini, 2001). The weak relations between child and parent perceptions can be interpreted in several ways. On the one hand, the low correlation suggests that parents may not know what is going on at school, at least in the realm of their children’s experiences with their peers. On the other hand, similarly low levels of agreement are found among peer, teacher, and parent reports (Ladd & Kochenderfer-Ladd, 2002) suggesting that there is no general consensus about “actual” levels of victimizations.

In light of the low levels of agreement about victimization, it is not surprising that there is little consensus across parents and children in the intervening psychological processes. If they are not starting from the same premise (i.e., peer victimization), it is understandable that their descriptions of down-stream processes, such as attributions and coping responses, would diverge. The important finding related to comparisons across sources of information is that parents may be relatively unaware of whether their children are suffering emotional distress caused by peer victimization. It is hard to imagine that parents can effectively help children cope if they are not fully aware of their children’s suffering. Furthermore, we do not know whether parents are explicitly communicating to their children why they believe they were victimized or how they think their children should cope with peer victimization. It could be the case that parents are suggesting coping strategies that do not mesh with their children’s abilities. For example, a child that is passive or shy may be very unlikely to act assertively when victimized, even if that is what parents suggest they do. This would help explain why there is little consensus across parent and child report data. Interventions could perhaps encourage greater disclosure and discussion between children and parents. By doing so, parents may become more aware of their children’s social experiences and internal adjustment and subsequently could become more effective at helping their children deal with their peer victimization experiences.

sec.title: Limitations of the Current Study
sec.p: In previous sections, the possible limitations of the measures used in this study were briefly discussed. The lack of any systematic relationship between coping responses and the other variables could indicate that broader scales are needed to better assess both parents’ and children’s coping responses in relation to peer victimization.

A second limitation concerns generalizability. The current study included primarily upper middle-class White participants, thus the results of the study can best be generalized to this population of children. It could be that perceptions of peer victimization may be higher among lower socioeconomic children. Crick and Grotpeter (1995) reported a somewhat higher mean level of peer victimization for their primarily lower socioeconomic participants than what the current study found. However, utilizing a more socioeconomically diverse sample, Kochenderfer-Ladd and Skinner (2002) reported a mean level of peer victimization more similar to the current study. Future research should strive to include more economically and ethnically diverse populations.

ack.p: I thank the administrators, teachers, and students and their parents from the McKinney Independent School District for their generous cooperation that made this work possible.

fn.p: The data presented in this article were collected in partial fulfillment of the requirements of the author’s PhD at The University of Texas at Dallas. Portions of this project were presented at the biennial meeting of the Society for Research on Child Development, April 2007, Boston, Massachusetts.
